passage.infon: ['Pharmaceuticals and personal care products (PPCPs)', 'Chlorine photolysis', 'Solar/free available chlorine', 'Advanced oxidation', 'Water treatment', '1']
passage.text: Photochemical oxidation of PPCPs using a combination of solar irradiation and free available chlorine
Relevant resource
True|False
Abstract

The degradation of pharmaceuticals and personal care products (PPCPs) by using solar photolysis in the presence of free available chlorine (FAC) was investigated in simulated drinking water. The combination of free available chlorine and sunlight irradiation dramatically accelerated the degradation of all the contaminants tested through the generation of hydroxyl radicals, reactive chlorine species (RCS) and ozone. Contaminants containing electron-donating moieties degraded quickly and were preferentially degraded by RCS and/or HO oxidation. Primidone, ibuprofen and atrazine, which contain electron-withdrawing moieties, were mainly degraded by HO . Trace amounts of O3 contributed greatly to carbamazepine's degradation. Degradation of PPCPs was accelerated in oxygenated solutions. Increasing chlorine concentrations barely enhanced removal of PPCPs bearing electron-withdrawing moieties. Higher pH generally decreased the degradation rate constants along with reduced levels of HO and Cl , but diclofenac, gemfibrozil, caffeine and carbamazepine had peak degradation rate constants at pH 7–8. The cytotoxicity using Chinese hamster ovary (CHO) cell did not show significant enhancement in solar/FAC treated water. Combining chlorination with sunlight may provide a simple and energy-efficient approach for improving the removal of organic contaminants during water treatment.
Tables

passage.text: The steady-state concentrations of HO and Cl and cumulative ozone concentrations during FAC + Light treatment.
Figures

The observed first-order degradation rate constants of PPCPs during FAC photolysis, FAC alone and sunlight irradiation alone. Conditions: initial [PPCP] = 500 ng L−1, [FAC] = 113 μM, [NOM] = 2.5 mg L−1 as DOC, pH = 7.0. Note: # too fast to obtain the kobs values with the estimated kobs larger than 0.6 s−1.

The removal of PPCPs contributed by sunlight, FAC, ozone, HO and RCS after 15 min of FAC photolysis treatment. Conditions: initial [PPCP] = 500 ng L−1, [FAC] = 113 μM, [NOM] = 2.5 mg L−1 as DOC, pH = 7.0.

PPCP removal during FAC photolysis without quenchers and with the presence of 50 mM TBA or with nitrogen purging. Conditions: initial [PPCP] = 500 ng L−1, [FAC] = 113 μM, [NOM] = 2.5 mg L−1 as DOC, pH = 7.0.

The fractional removal (R) of PPCPs contributed by sunlight, FAC, ozone, HO and RCS after 15 min of FAC photolysis treatment with various FAC doses (70–225 μM). Conditions: initial [PPCP] = 500 ng L−1, [NOM] = 2.5 mg L−1 as DOC, pH = 7.0. Note: R is calculated based on initial PPCP concentrations. The contribution from ozone at a FAC dose of 70 μM was not calculated as the ozone concentrations were below the 10−9 M detection limit.

The fractional removal (R) of PPCPs contributed by sunlight, FAC, ozone, HO and RCS after 15 min of FAC photolysis treatment with various pHs (6.0–9.0). Conditions: initial [PPCP] = 500 ng L−1, [FAC] = 113 μM, [NOM] = 2.5 mg L−1 as DOC. Note: R is calculated based on initial PPCP concentrations.
Graphical abstract
keywords
['Pharmaceuticals and personal care products (PPCPs)', 'Chlorine photolysis', 'Solar/free available chlorine', 'Advanced oxidation', 'Water treatment', '1']
Introduction

Pharmaceuticals and personal care products (PPCPs) have been detected widely in aqueous environments at concentrations ranging from nanogram to microgram per liter ( ; ; ; ). Free available chlorine (FAC, HOCl/OCl−), the most commonly-used disinfectant in municipal water and wastewater treatment, can partially remove some PPCPs containing phenolic and primary amine moieties ( ; ; ; ). However, some widely occurred PPCPs such as caffeine, ibuprofen, and carbamazepine, can be barely reduced ( ; ; ). Photolysis of FAC generates highly reactive species such as hydroxyl radicals (HO ), chlorine radicals (Cl ) and ground-state atomic oxygen (O(3P)) (Eqs. ) ( ; ; ; ). At wavelengths <320 nm, singlet-state atomic oxygen (O(1D)) can be generated through OCl− photolysis (Eq. ) ( ), and it reacts quickly with H2O (1.8 × 1010 M−1 s−1) to generate H2O2 and HO ( ). The photochemical reactions of FAC in water include: (1) HOCl↔OCl−+H+pKa=7.54at25°C (2) HOCl→hvHO•+Cl•λ<400nm (3) OCl−→hvO•−+Cl•λ<400nm (4) OCl−→hvO3P+Cl−λ<400nm (5) OCl−→hvOD1+Cl−λ<320nm After the generation of primary radicals (HO and Cl ), they undergo subsequent reactions to produce Cl2 − and ClO as secondary radicals (Eqs. ) ( ; ). O(3P) can react with O2 and yield the ozone under oxic conditions (Eq. ) ( ). (6) Cl•+Cl−→Cl2•−k=8.0×109M−1s−1 (7) HOCl/OCl−+HO•→H2O/HO−+OCl•k=0.5/1.9×109M−1s−1 (8) HOCl/OCl−+Cl•→HCl/Cl−+OCl•k=3.0/8.3×109M−1s−1 (9) O3P+O2→O3k=4.0×109M−1s−1 Reactive species such as HO , reactive chlorine species (RCS, including Cl , Cl2 − and ClO ) and O3, can be beneficial for chlorine-resistant PPCP removal ( ; ; ; ; ; ). After the identification of HO and Cl during photodecomposition of FAC ( ; ; ), extensive studies have been conducted on the removal of PPCPs through FAC photolysis under UV irradiation at 254 nm. The results have shown that the elimination of PPCPs by UV/FAC process is more effective than FAC alone ( ; ; ; ). HO contributes to over 60% of the removal of metronidazole, ibuprofen, dimetridazole, tinidazole and ornidazole at pH 7.0 under UV254 irradiation of FAC ( ; ; ). Cl contributes to about 65% of the removal of benzoic acid at pH 6.0, though the relative contributions change with variations in chlorine dose and pH ( ). Cl2 − reacts with olefinic compounds and aromatic compounds very rapidly and the reaction rate constants of Cl2 − with sorbic acid, phenol and hydroquinone are also over 108 M−1 s−1 ( ). ClO has fast reaction rate constants with carbamazepine, caffeine, gemfibrozil and bezafibrate (>108 M−1 s−1) ( ; ). O3 reacts preferentially with compounds containing electron-donating moieties such as phenols, olefins and amines ( ; ; ) and O3 has high rate constants in reactions with diclofenac, bisphenol-A, carbamazepine and sulfamethoxazole (>105 M−1 s−1) ( ; ; ). Using sunlight (λ > 290 nm) or artificial UV light for photochemical inactivation of FAC is attractive considering the extended absorption spectrum of HOCl and OCl− above 300 nm ( ; ) (Fig. S1 in the supplementary information). HOCl's maximum absorbance is at 235 nm, and OCl− has a maximum molar absorption coefficient of 359 M−1 cm−1 at 292 nm (Fig. S1) ( ). The tail of HOCl and OCl−'s absorbance spectrum overlaps with the solar spectrum at 290–400 nm with OCl− as the major absorption species. The quantum yields (Φ) of HOCl and OCl− vary with the irradiation wavelength and pH. ΦOH from HOCl photolysis was reported to be 0.62 and 1.0 under 254 nm and 313 nm, respectively and ΦOH from OCl− photolysis was 0.55, 0.127 and 0.08 under 254 nm, 313 nm and 365 nm, respectively ( ; ; ; ). Recently, the formation of reactive species during chlorine photolysis as a function of irradiation wavelength (254, 311, and 365 nm) have been investigated by Bulman's group ( ). HO and Cl steady-state concentrations were found to be highest using 254 and 311 nm irradiation, whereas the maximum cumulative concentration of ozone was observed in 311 and 365 nm irradiation. Thus, the reactive species levels under solar irradiation (>290 nm) may be different from those under 254 nm UV irradiation. Solar irradiation of FAC has been used to degrade methylene blue and cyclohexanoic acid in ultrapure water at pH 10.0 ( ) and naphthenic acids in oily water ( ). Their results have demonstrated the feasibility to use FAC solar irradiation process to treat organics polluted water. Solar irradiation with FAC also dramatically enhances inactivation of Cryptosporidium parvum oocysts and Bacillus subtilis endospores compared to FAC or sunlight alone ( ; ), which is attributed to combined HO and O3 attack. Solar photolysis with FAC also greatly enhances the removal of PPCPs including carbamazepine in ultrapure water ( ; ). However, the water components, such as natural organic matter, can greatly scavenge the reactive species and shift their contribution to pollutant removal. PPCP removal and the contribution of the various reactive species to their removal in drinking water relevant conditions are still not well investigated. As such, this study was designed to investigate the effectiveness of combining FAC with solar irradiation to reduce PPCPs in drinking water relevant conditions. The elimination of PPCPs at ng/L level in synthetic water containing natural organic matter and real water were examined. The factors influencing the degradation kinetics and the mechanisms involved were explored in drinking water under simulated and natural sunlight. 2
Materials and methods
Chemicals

The structures, chemical properties and the molar concentrations of the 14 PPCPs tested are listed in Tables S1 and S2 in the Supporting Information (SI). These compounds were chosen due to their prevalence in surface waters ( ; ). A stock solution of natural organic matter (NOM) was prepared by dissolving Suwannee River NOM isolate (Cat. No. 2R101N, International Humic Substances Society) in ultrapure water and filtering it through a 0.45 μm glass fiber membrane pre-ashed at 500 °C. Two water samples were collected from two water treatment plants in South China after sand filtration and were filtered with 0.45 μm membrane filters before use. Water properties are listed in Table S3. The details of the other chemicals are provided in Text S1. 2.2
Experimental procedures

A Q-SUN Xenon Test Chamber (Xe-1) solar simulator equipped with a Daylight-Q filter (>290 nm) was employed for all of the irradiation experiments. The total absolute irradiance spectrum of the solar simulator over the wavelength range 290–800 nm as shown in Fig. S1 was measured using an Ocean Optics USB–4000 spectrometer. The light intensity between 290 and 400 nm was fixed at 35.5 W m−2, and the total photo irradiance over those wavelengths was determined to be 1.1 × 10−8 Einstein cm−2 s−1 using p-nitroanisole/pyridine actinometry ( ). The 15-min irradiation corresponded to a fluence of 3.2 × 104 J m−2. All of the solutions were prepared in 80 mL cylindrical, quartz glass and sealed vials. The solution and the vials are kept at 25 °C by putting in a recirculating water bath (Fig. S1). The experiments tested three basic approaches: (i) exposure to FAC without irradiation (designated FAC only), (ii) simulated sunlight irradiation without the presence of FAC (Light only), and (iii) irradiation of FAC solutions with simulated sunlight (FAC + Light). Each testing solutions contained 2.5 mg C L−1 NOM and PPCPs (500 ng L−1 each). The mixtures were buffered at pH 6.0, 7.0 or 8.0 using 10 mM phosphate buffer or at pH 9.0 using 10 mM borate buffer. Noted that the buffer composition has negligible effect on PPCP degradation kinetics. The FAC doses varied from 70 to 225 μM. The concentration of dissolved oxygen (DO) remained constant during the irradiation experiments and was measured to be around 260 μM (8.3 mg L−1). In some experiments, the solution was purged with nitrogen for 30 min before irradiation, which resulted in low DO levels of about 14.1 ± 4.7 μM (0.45 ± 0.15 mg L−1) during the experiments. The solution containing NOM and PPCPs was mixed first before reaction. When adding free chlorine, the mixture was simultaneously exposed to solar light. Samples were collected at intervals over 15 min and were quenched with sodium thiosulfate, followed by PPCP analysis. A separate test was conducted for evaluating the formation of disinfection byproducts and cytotoxicity. 2.3
Determination of reactive species concentrations

Nitrobenzene (NB) and benzoate (BA) at 0.2 μM were added to the solutions before the FAC photolysis as probes for HO and Cl analysis, respectively. NB reacts rapidly with HO , but is inert to ozone (k = 9.0 × 10−2 M−1 s−1) and RCS ( ; ; ). Benzoate (BA) reacts rapidly with HO (k = 5.9 × 109 M−1 s−1) and Cl (k = 1.8 × 1010 M−1 s−1), but it reacts slowly with Cl2 − (k = 2.0 × 106 M−1 s−1) and is inert to ozone ( ; ; ; ). The steady state concentrations of HO and Cl were inferred indirectly by measuring their depletion according to Eqs. . (10) kNB′=kHO·,NBHO·ss+ksolar,NB (11) kBA′=kHO·,BAHO·ss+kCl·,BACl·ss+ksolar,BA Here k′NB and k′BA represent the observed first-order rate constants of NB's and BA's disappearance during the FAC + light treatment, respectively. ksolar, NB and ksolar, BA represent the observed first-order rate constants of NB and BA's disappearance under solar irradiation only. kHO ,NB is the reaction rate constant between NB and HO , taken as 3.9 × 109 M−1 s−1 ( ). kHO ,BA and kCl ,BA are the reaction rate constants between BA and HO and Cl , which were 5.9 × 109 M−1 s−1 and 1.8 × 1010 M−1 s−1, respectively ( ; ). The details of the tests are presented in Text S2 in the SI. The ozone concentrations were quantified by evaluating the benzaldehyde yields from cinnamic acid conversion following a previously published method ( ), the details of which are provided in Text S2. Briefly, a solution containing 1 mM NH4Cl and 30 μM cinnamic acid was added to the test solutions at pre-defined times during the irradiation. NH4Cl was included to quench residual FAC by converting it to NH2Cl, thereby preventing further generation of O3 via FAC photolysis. After 5 min, excess Na2S2O3 was added to quench any residual NH2Cl and the solution's benzaldehyde content was measured chromatographically. Attempts were made to measure ClO2 in selected experiments using the dye 2,2-azino-bis(3-ethyl-benzothiazoline)-6-sulfonic acid-diammonium (ABTS) ( ). Those measurements were undertaken in the same manner as described above for O3, except that glycine was substituted for NH4Cl, and ABTS for cinnamic acid. The concentration of ClO2 was found to be lower than the detection limit (<0.1 μM). 2.4
Calculating the contributions from FAC, light, and reactive species

The degradation of PPCPs during FAC + Light treatment involve contributions from direct solar photolysis along with oxidation by FAC, O3, HO and RCS. The degradation of a specific PPCP (expressed as S) can be written as Eq. . (12) −dSdt=kLight′S+kFACFACS+kO3O3S+kHO·HO·S+kRCSRCSS [S] is the concentration of a specific PPCP; kLight is the pseudo–first-order rate constant of the PPCP's decay under solar photolysis (Table S5), kFAC, kO3, kHO and kRCS represent the apparent second-order rate constants specific to the pH between the PPCP and FAC, O3, HO and the RCS, respectively. More detail is provided in Text S3 and Table S1. The removal attributed to each process was calculated separately as shown in Text S4. The fractional removal (R) at a specific time t can be expressed as Eq. . (13) R=S0−StS0=∫0tkLight′SdtS0+∫0tkFACFACSdtS0+∫0tkO3O3SdtS0+∫0tkHO·HO·SdtS0+∫0tkRCSRCSSdtS0=RLight+RFAC+RO3+RHO·+RRCS The contribution percentages attributed to each species hereafter refer to the percentages calculated based on the PPCPs' original concentrations, not their overall removal. It should be noted that RRCS is not able to obtain experimentally and it is calculated based on the subtraction of the other R's (RLight, RFAC, RO3 and RHO ) from overall removal. This method has been used in many previous studies ( ; ; ; ; ). 2.5
Analytical methods

DOC concentrations were measured using a Shimadzu TOC-VCPH analyzer. Chlorine residuals were analyzed using the N,N-diethyl-p-phenylenediamine/ferrous ammonium sulfate titration ( ). A solid phase extraction system coupled with a liquid chromatograph and a triple quadrupole mass spectrometer (Agilent 1290-6430) with a Flexcube module was applied in the PPCP analyses. 1.8 mL of the analyzed solution was injected. The experimental setup is described in detail in Text S5 and the conditions for each PPCP are provided in Table S6. The concentrations of nitrobenzene, benzoate and benzaldehyde were measured at 265 nm, 227 nm and 248 nm using a Dionex Ultimate 3000 HPLC system equipped with a Syncronis C18 column (4.6 × 250 mm, 5 μm) and a diode array detector. The cytotoxicity was assessed using the Chinese hamster ovary (CHO) cell line. Each sample was concentrated by solid phase extraction (SPE) using Bond Elut PPL cartridge (Agilent, USA). In brief, each sample (300 mL) was passed through a cartridge preconditioned by 6 mL methanol at 3 mL/min and the cartridge was dried by passing nitrogen through. Then the resin was eluted with 2 mL methanol, followed by 2 mL acetone and 2 mL dichloromethane. The extract was dried under a stream of nitrogen and stored at 4 °C. The concentration procedures recovered 76 ± 2.4% organic carbon with details provided in Text S8. DBPs including trichloromethane (TCM), chloral hydrate (CH), 1,1,1-trichloropropanone (TCP), 1,1-dichloropropanone (DCP), dichloroacetaldehyde (DCAL), dichloroacetonitrile (DCAN), trichloronitromethane (TCNM) were concentrated by liquid-liquid extraction and analyzed by a gas chromatograph (GC) (Agilent 7890A) equipped with micro-electron capture detector (μECD) according to the USEPA Method 551.1. Trichloroacetic acid (TCAA) and dichloroacetic acid (DCAA) were extracted and derivatized with acidified methanol before analysis by GC-μECD following USEPA Method 552 with details provided in Text S9. 3
Results and discussion
PPCP degradation kinetics

shows the observed first-order degradation rate constants (kobs) of the PPCPs at pH 7.0 during exposure to FAC alone (FAC only), simulated sunlight alone (Light only), and FAC and simulated sunlight together (FAC + Light). Exposure to sunlight alone was ineffective in reducing most of the PPCPs with the exception of tinidazole (5.3 × 10−4 s−1), diclofenac (5.2 × 10−4 s−1) and sulfamethoxazole (1.4 × 10−4 s−1). Treatment with FAC alone was effective for degrading cephalexin and sulfamethoxazole. Cephalexin was completely degraded after 10s giving an estimated kobs larger than 0.6 s−1. Diclofenac had a modest removal rate constant of 1.5 × 10−3 s−1, while the remaining PPCPs were barely reduced under FAC treatment alone. However, the combination of FAC and sunlight irradiation dramatically accelerated the degradation of all of the PPCPs tested except cephalexin as its reactions were too fast to obtain kobs values. After 15 min of FAC photolysis, all of the PPCPs were degraded by >50%. The degradation rate constants of tinidazole, ibuprofen, primidone and atrazine were among the lowest (7.7 × 10−4–1.6 × 10−3 s−1), but the other PPCPs' degradation rate constants were all higher than 2.7 × 10−3 s−1. The degradation of cephalexin and sulfamethoxazole were fastest, depleted within 10 s. Calculated degradation half-lives are shown in . Atrazine's half-life was 15 min, but the others were all <8.5 min. It should be noted that FAC concentrations in the dark reaction showed about 15.6% decrease during 15-min reaction, mainly due to the reaction with NOM. While under solar irradiation, FAC concentrations decreased by 71.3%. The greatly enhanced decrease when FAC is combined with sunlight indicated the formation of the reactive species (HO , RCS, and O3) from FAC photolysis. 3.2
The importance of reactive species

The contributions to the degradation of PPCPs from sunlight irradiation, FAC, O3, HO and RCS after 15 min of FAC photolysis are presented in . The PPCPs were grouped into four groups based on their reactivity with the reactive species. The Group I compounds were primarily degraded by RCS (>50%), which included diclofenac, gemfibrozil, caffeine, iopromide, bezafibrate and metoprolol. Atenolol (47% by RCS) and tinidazole (27% by RCS) were also included in the Group I due to the major contribution of RCS in their degradation after excluding direct photolysis. The Group II compounds—ibuprofen, primidone and atrazine—were primarily degraded by HO (>50%). Carbamazepine is alone in Group III and is primarily degraded by O3 (>50%). Those compounds with very fast reaction rate constants with FAC (>900 M−1 s−1) during FAC photolysis (reduced in <10 s) were assigned to Group IV, including cephalexin and sulfamethoxazole. As their reactions were too fast to obtain kobs values, they were not discussed further. The Group I compounds had degradation rate constants >2.7 × 10−3 s−1 (except for tinidazole) and half-lives <4.5 min (except t1/2 = 7.3 min for tinidazole). These compounds generally contained electron-donating moieties such as the amine group (diclofenac, bezafibrate, metoprolol and atenolol), the methoxybenzene group in gemfibrozil and the methylimidazole group in caffeine and tinidazole. The Group II compounds had the lowest rate constants during FAC photolysis with half-lives between 7.4 and 15 min. They did not contain electron-donating moieties and were degraded primarily by non-selective hydroxyl radicals. Group III's carbamazepine reacted rapidly with O3 (3.0 × 105 M−1 s−1) ( ). The ozone exposure (CTO3 = ∫0tO3dt) detected under photolysis of FAC (113 μM) at pH 7.0 were around 0.6 μM min (Fig. S4b) after 15-min reaction and the ozone concentration were around 10−2 μM (Figs. S2 and S4a). The ozone concentrations and the ozone exposure detected in this study in the presence of 2.5 mg C L−1 NOM were much lower than those previously reported in ultrapure water as NOM could greatly scavenge the reactive species ( ; ; ). Also the lower irradiance intensity between 290 and 400 nm of this study (35.5 W m−2) may inhibit the formation of ozone. It should be noted that the ozone concentrations varied with reaction time (Fig. S2). At the beginning of the experiments, OCl− was at high levels and competed with oxygen on O(3P) (Eqs. ). With time prolonging and chlorine consumption, oxygen may compete over OCl− to form ozone. Meanwhile, the consumption of ozone attributed to multiple sources, such as NOM, PPCPs in solutions, oxidants (e.g., OCl−, 1.2 × 102 M−1 s−1) ( ) and products (e.g. ClO2−, 4.0 × 106 M−1 s−1) ( ). Due to the low ozone concentrations in the system, ozone had no significant contributions to the degradation of majority PPCPs unless the PPCP had very high reaction rate constants with ozone (e.g., >105 M−1 s−1) such as carbamazepine. O3 oxidation contributed greatly to carbamazepine's degradation (89%). Although diclofenac and sulfamethoxazole also reacted quickly with O3 (6.8 × 105 and 5.5 × 105 M−1 s−1, respectively) ( ; ), O3 oxidation's contribution to their degradation was extremely low (<3%). Reaction with RCS seemed to be the dominant pathway for diclofenac, due to its high reactivity towards RCS ( ). The roles of HO , RCS, and O3 in FAC photolysis were further explored by evaluating PPCP degradation (1) in the presence of tert-butanol (TBA), and (2) in the absence of oxygen. The results are shown in . TBA scavenges HO , Cl , ClO and O(3P) with rate constants of 6.0 × 108, 3.0 × 108, 1.3 × 107 and 3.8 × 107 M−1 s−1, respectively ( ; ). Thus, adding 50 mM TBA could scavenge about 98% of HO , 90% of Cl , 85% of ClO and 60% of O(3P) with calculation details in Text S6. Though Cl2 − had a lower reaction rate constant with TBA (700 M−1 s−1) ( ) and was barely quenched once formed, Cl2 − concentrations were also reduced due to the significant quenching of Cl upon TBA addition. The degradation rate constants of most of the Group I compounds were reduced by over 69% except only 25% reduction in iopromide. The lack of significant decrease in iopromide's degradation may be due to the main contribution of Cl2 − in its elimination. Another possibility is that the products from TBA quenching of reactive species may also contribute to the removal of iopromide ( ). The degradation of the Group II compounds (ibuprofen, primidone and atrazine) and carbamazepine was almost completely inhibited in the presence of TBA. Deoxygenation inhibited the formation of O3 via Eq. . Deoxygenation reduced carbamazepine's degradation rate constant by 41%, but this was much less than the 89% contribution from O3 oxidation, probably due to the incomplete elimination of oxygen from the solution. Dissolved oxygen was detected at a concentration of 0.45 (±0.15) mg L−1 in the solutions after purging with nitrogen at pH 7.0. O3 was still present and was measured directly, but its concentration was reduced by about 40% in comparison to that without nitrogen purging. Interestingly, the degradation of the Group I and Group II PPCPs was also decreased by 8 to 48% in deoxygenated solutions, although O3 made little or no contribution to their degradation. This was probably because the deoxygenation reduced the levels of HO by 39% and the levels of ClO and Cl2 − as well ( ). In the nitrogen-purged solutions, O(3P) mainly reacted with OCl− to form chlorite (ClO2−) (9.4 × 109 M−1 s−1) (Eq. ) ( ), but the chlorite concentrations were lower than the detection limit (<1 μM) due to its rapid oxidation by O(3P), HO , ClO and Cl2 − (Eqs. ) ( ; ). As ClO2− could be further oxidized to chlorate (ClO3−) (1.59 × 1010 M−1 s−1), more chlorate formation was observed in solutions with nitrogen-purging than without purging (Fig. S3b). It should be noted that both chlorite and chlorate were below the detection limits at a low FAC dose of 28 μM. Thus the preferential scavenging of O(3P) by OCl− rather than O2 in nitrogen-purged solutions was one reason for the reduced levels of HO , ClO and Cl2 −. Meanwhile, the oxygen levels affected the FAC consumption. More FAC consumption was observed in the first 3 min, which was mainly due to the increased consumption of O(3P) by OCl− in low oxygen levels (Fig. S3e). However, with reaction proceeding, more FAC residual were found in the deoxygenation condition. This may be due to that byproduct chlorite also consumed O(3P), narrowing the difference in FAC degradation by O(3P) from different oxygen concentrations. Meanwhile, as lower concentrations of HO and Cl were present in the N2-purged condition, higher FAC residuals were observed in the N2-purged condition than in the without N2-purged condition with time prolonging. In addition, the reduction in PPCP degradation rate constant in the nitrogen-purged solutions in comparison to that without nitrogen purging was higher at pH 8.0 than those at pH 6.0 and 7.0, primarily attributed to OCl− as the dominant species (76% OCl−/24% HOCl) at pH 8.0. The more reaction of O(3P) with OCl− could lead to the enhanced levels of chlorite and chlorate. This was in fact the confirmation of the highest yields of chlorate at pH 8.0 as shown in Fig. S3. Therefore, oxygen concentrations had significant impacts on the levels of the reactive species. (14) O3P+O2→O3k=4.0×109M−1s−1 (15) O3P+OCl−→ClO2−k=9.4×109M−1s−1 (16) O3P+OH−→HO2−k=4.2×108M−1s−1 (17) O3P+ClO2−→ClO3−k=1.59×1010M−1s−1 (18) ClO•+ClO2−→ClO−+ClO2k=9.4×108M−1s−1 (19) Cl2•−+ClO2−→2Cl−+ClO2•k=1.3×108M−1s−1 (20) HO•+ClO2−→HO−+ClO2k=7.0×109M−1s−1 It should be noted that O(3P) has also been reported to have oxidative capacity towards olefines and aromatic compounds ( ; ). The reduced degradation rates of the PPCPs tested in the nitrogen-purged solutions suggested a negligible role of O(3P) in PPCP degradation, at least at pH 7.0. Chlorite and chlorate formation were below 1 μM (0.067 mg L−1) and 1.6 μM (0.13 mg L−1) at a FAC dose of 113 μM at pH 7.0 (Fig. S3b), respectively. The highest chlorate concentrations reached 7 μM (0.58 mg L−1) in nitrogen-purged solutions at pH 8.0 (Fig. S3c), which were below the World Health Organization regulations and Chinese regulation guidelines of drinking water (<0.7 mg L−1 for chlorite and <0.7 mg L−1 for chlorate). Cautions should still be paid to treat water with low levels of dissolved oxygen and alkaline pH. 3.3
Effect of FAC dose

The variation in the kobs as a function of FAC dosage was shown in , which showed that the kobs for the Group I and Group III PPCPs increased roughly 1.4 to 4.3-folds with FAC dose increasing from 70 to 225 μM. The kobs for ibuprofen and primidone in Group II, however, did not vary significantly with the chlorine dosage, whereas the kobs for atrazine increased 21% at a chlorine dosage of 225 μM compared with that of 70 μM chlorine addition. The enhanced degradation rates of caffeine and carbamazepine with increasing FAC concentrations were observed in previous UV/FAC studies ( ; ). The degradation rates of benzoic acid, atrazine and ibuprofen also increased with increasing FAC doses, but reached plateaus at chlorine dose above 50 μM ( ; ; ). also shows the changes in the percentage contributions from sunlight irradiation, FAC, O3, HO , and RCS after 15-min reaction at various FAC doses (113, 170 and 225 μM). The contribution from ozone at a FAC dose of 70 μM was not calculated as the ozone concentrations were below the detection limit at 10−9 M. Increased contribution percentages from FAC oxidation were observed for bezafibrate, atenolol and tinidazole due to the increasing FAC exposure (dose × time). The contribution of RCS generally increased for the Group I PPCPs except for gemfibrozil, diclofenac and tinidazole. The measured steady-state concentrations of Cl showed little variation with the changes in the FAC doses except at 170 μM ( ). With increasing FAC doses, the scavenging effect by FAC also increased. The resulting Cl concentrations depended on the counterbalance between the formation rate and scavenging rate of Cl . The reason for the low Cl concentration at a FAC dose of 170 μM is unclear. Further studies on the effect of FAC doses would be suggested. The concentrations of Cl2 − and ClO might increase due to the reactions shown in Eqs. with increasing chloride concentrations and increasing FAC dose. The overall increase in RCS thus led to significantly enhanced Group I PPCP degradation with increasing FAC dose. The contribution from HO showed small variations for all of the PPCPs with increasing FAC dose as the measured steady-state HO concentrations shown in did not vary significantly (from 1.39 × 10−13 M to 1.29 × 10−13 M at FAC doses of 113 μM and 225 μM, respectively). The Group II compounds (ibuprofen, primidone and atrazine) also showed little or no enhancement in their degradation rate constants with increasing FAC doses. With increasing FAC doses, both HO formation rate and scavenging rate increased as HOCl and OCl− were radical scavengers of HO . The resulting steady-state HO concentrations did not vary significantly (<20%) with increasing FAC doses. Previous studies on FAC photolysis under UV254 irradiation showed that the HO concentration reached plateaus at chlorine doses in the range of 100–1000 μM ( ; ). Also the contribution of HO to the degradation of caffeine, bezafibrate and ibuprofen in UV/FAC treatment remained stable with increasing chlorine doses ( ; ; ). The contribution from ozone oxidation also increased with increasing FAC dosage, and ozone contributed 3–6% to the degradation of gemfibrozil, diclofenac, atenolol and metoprolol at a FAC dose of 225 μM. However, the contribution of ozone to carbamazepine degradation decreased. The ozone exposure (∫0tO3dt) during the 15-min period was enhanced by 350% as the FAC dose increased from 113 to 225 μM (Fig. S4). The contribution of ozone was attenuated due to the fast degradation rate of carbamazepine (1.88 × 10−2 s−1) at a FAC dose of 225 μM compared to that at 113 μM (7.66 × 10−3 s−1), greatly reducing its exposure time to ozone from 10 min to 3 min. 3.4
Effect of pH

pH has been reported to be an important factor affecting PPCP oxidation ( ; ; ). The PPCPs showed different change features of kobs as pH increased from 6.0 to 9.0 in . Diclofenac, caffeine and gemfibrozil exhibited similar degradation rate constants at pH 7.0 and 8.0, which were higher than those at pH 6.0 and 9.0. The other PPCPs in Group I and Group II showed decreasing kobs as the pH increased from 6.0 to 9.0. The degradation rate constant of carbamazepine was found to be highest at pH 8.0. also shows the change feature of the percentage contributions of sunlight irradiation, FAC, O3, HO and RCS after 15 min of reaction during FAC photolysis at various pHs. The contribution percentages from HO oxidation decreased with increasing pH for all of the PPCPs. The kobs for the Group II compounds, mainly contributed by HO oxidation, thus decreased by 57 to 75% as the pH increased from 6.0 to 9.0. The contribution percentages from RCS oxidation for the Group I compounds varied with pH, which led to diverse variations in kobs for the various Group I compounds. The contribution from ozone oxidation was significant for metoprolol and atenolol at pH 9.0, but ozone's contribution to carbamazepine degradation at pH 9.0 was much lower than that at other pHs. Increasing pH shifted free chlorine from HOCl to OCl−. On the one hand, pH influenced the quantum yield of free chlorine during photolysis and the formation of reactive species. For example, the quantum yield of formation of HO from HOCl is 1 mol Einstein−1 at 313 nm ( ; ), whereas the quantum yields of formation of O − and Cl from OCl− at 313 nm and 365 nm are 0.127 and 0.08 mol Einstein−1, respectively ( ). The quantum yields of formation of O3(P) from OCl− is 0.075 mol Einstein−1 at 313 nm and 0.28 mol Einstein−1 at 365 nm ( ). On the other hand, pH affected the consumption of radicals by free chlorine. As OCl− reacted faster with HO and Cl than HOCl, the steady-state concentration of HO and Cl would be much lower at higher pH (Eqs. ) ( ; ). As the pH increased from 6.0 to 9.0, the measured steady-state HO and Cl concentrations decreased from 4.11 × 10−13 M to 7.6 × 10−14 M and from 3.37 × 10−14 M to 1.11 × 10−14 M, respectively ( ). The trends in experimental HO and Cl steady-state concentrations with pH variation were also observed during chlorine photolysis using 365 and 311 nm irradiation ( ). ClO could be formed after the reaction of HOCl/OCl− with HO and Cl (Eqs. ) and the faster scavenging rate by OCl− may result in higher levels of ClO with increasing pH. Thus, the pH effect on the RCS formation was intricate, leading to diverse variations in the degradation rates of PPCPs. Similar observations were also found in previous UV/FAC studies. The degradation rates of PPCPs mainly attacked by HO , such as ibuprofen and atrazine, decreased with increasing pH from 6 to 9 ( ; ). Diclofenac and gemfibrozil also displayed higher degradation rate constants at pH 7 than at pH 6 and 8 during UV/FAC treatment ( ). Caffeine having peak degradation rates at pH 7–8 under solar/FAC treatment, however, showed decreasing trend with increasing pH under UV/FAC treatment ( ). The concentrations of ozone were time-dependent, consistent with the observations of previous studies ( ). In the first 3 min the ozone concentrations were in the order pH 6.0 > pH 7.0 > pH 8.0 > pH 9.0. After that the order became pH 8.0 > pH 7.0 > pH 6.0 > pH 9.0 (Fig. S4). It is not clear why ozone concentrations showed different pH-dependent trend before and after 3 min. The variation between ozone generation rate and consumption rate seemed to change with reaction time. With the shift speciation of the FAC to OCl−, the O3 levels increased after 3 min as the pH increased from 6.0 to 8.0 due to the enhanced formation of O(3P) levels from OCl− photolysis (Eq. ) (Fig. S4). However, as the pH increased further to 9.0, the O3 levels became lowest due to the enhanced quenching of O(3P) by OCl− (Eq. ) and HO– (Eq. ) and the scavenging of O3 by OCl− ( ). The consumption rate of ozone by NOM was also faster at higher pHs ( ; ). It remained unclear why the pH effects on ozone formation differed in the initial several minutes from those later, but it could affect the degradation rate constants of the PPCPs due to their different ozone exposure periods. With respect to carbamazepine, the ozone contribution percentage was highest at pH 6.0 and then decreased with increasing pH, which was consistent with the ozone levels in the initial 3 min. Gemfibrozil and diclofenac also displayed the similar trends in terms of ozone contribution. Interestingly, ozone greatly contributed to the degradation of metoprolol and atenolol at pH 9.0, despite of the low ozone levels. As discussed earlier, ozone had significant contributions to the degradation of PPCPs with very high reaction rate constants with ozone (e.g., >105 M−1 s−1). Metoprolol and atenolol had pH-dependent reaction rate constants with ozone, which were much higher at pH 9.0 than at lower pHs (1.27 × 105 M−1 s−1 and 1.4 × 105 M−1 s−1 at pH 9.0 for metoprolol and atenolol, respectively in comparison to 2.68 × 102 M−1 s−1 and 5.0 × 102 M−1 s−1 at pH 6.0) (see Table S1) ( ; ; ). Though the contribution of ozone to their degradation was negligible at acidic and neutral pH, over 49% degradation of metoprolol and atenolol were attributed by ozone oxidation at pH 9.0 instead. 3.5
Natural sunlight irradiation and toxicity evaluation

Two water samples collected after sand filtration in two water treatment plants were spiked with PPCPs before dosing FAC and being irradiated under natural sunlight. The experimental details are provided in Text S7. The elimination of PPCPs after 5 and 15 min of FAC photolysis is displayed in Fig. S7. The Group I and Group III compounds except tinidazol were degraded by over 93% after 5 min, and the Group II compounds were degraded by over 60% after 15 min. These results were consistent with those in the NOM solutions using simulated sunlight irradiation. It is known that chlorine application leads to the formation of toxic disinfection byproducts (DBPs). During FAC photolysis, RCS and O3 are formed, which also contribute to byproduct formation. Thus, we used the Chinese hamster ovary (CHO) cell line to evaluate the cytotoxicity of the treated water. As shown in Fig. S8(a), the CHO cytotoxicity did not show great enhancement in solar/FAC treated samples in comparison to those without treatment and solar irradiation only. Though DBPs including trihalomethanes, haloacetic acids, chloral hydrate and haloacetonitriles were found in solar/FAC treated water as that in (Fig. S8(b)), the enhancement in CHO cytotoxicity was not obvious. The water samples were pre-concentrated for 300 times by using solid phase extraction before cytotoxicity tests and the volatile DBPs may be lost ( ). The cytotoxicity of the retained fractions after 300 times of concentration was not high. Other toxicity assays may be used to further examine the associated toxicity of the treated water. It should be noted that the DBP levels reported here were those formed from solar/FAC treatment. Under drinking water treatment, higher DBP levels will be expected after longer contact time with FAC in the distribution systems ( ; ). The potential risk should be considered in future studies. 4
Conclusions

The in-situ generation of HO , RCS (Cl , Cl2 − and ClO ) and O3 during solar irradiation of free available chlorine greatly accelerated the PPCP degradation in simulated drinking water and real water samples. PPCPs containing electron-donating moieties and PPCPs having high reaction rate constants with O3 (>105 M−1 s−1) can be quickly degraded with half-life time less than 7.3 min. PPCPs short of electron-donating moieties were degraded mainly by HO with half-life time ranging from 7.39 to 14.96 min. Oxygen had great impacts on PPCP degradation rates with higher oxygen concentrations enhancing PPCP elimination. Enhancing FAC doses had minor effects on PPCP degradation. Acidic pH generally favored PPCP degradation, but some PPCPs had peaked degradation rate constants at pH 7–8. The cytotoxicity did not show significant enhancement in solar/FAC treated water. Combining chlorination with sunlight may provide a simple and energy-efficient approach to improving the removal of organic contaminants during water treatment. Chlorine photolysis can potentially be used in wastewater treatment in constructed ponds or in wetlands for organic pollutant removal. The process is particularly well suited for use in small-scale drinking water treatment facilities. The water depth should be kept shallow to allow enough sunlight to penetrate. Chlorine photolysis can also potentially be used in wastewater treatment in constructed ponds or in wetlands for organic pollutant removal. Solar water disinfection and chlorination are both well-established, inexpensive means of water disinfection in such economies. Their simple combination can provide a higher level of both pathogen inactivation and organic contaminant elimination. Appendix A
